BALTIMORE

With a squad of fifty men practicing three times a week at the
Baltimore Athletic Club tinder the
direction of Coach Murphy, prospects for a successful season for
the first basket-ball team representing Hopkins are exceedingly
bright. The first practice session
was called by Manager I.3ascom
Kennady on Monday, November
17, and since then practice has
been held regularly on Mondays,
Wednesdays and Thursdays, from
9 to 11. P. M.
On the squad are several freshmen who were formerly prominent
members of local "prep" school
fives. Owens and Beigle, of
Friends School and City College;
respectively, have both made enviable records as forwards. The position of center is also being hotly
contested for by two very capable
fresh, Bauernschmidt, of City College, and Ward,of Baltimore Polytechnic Institute. Among the
graduate students eligible to play
are five men from the medical college—Cuano, Love, Sherrick, Weinert and Sheffey, all of whom have
been connected with teams .of
other colleges. The remainder of
the squad, which is composed of
undergraduates, includes athletes
of stich calibre as "Bill" and "Ed"
Wood, Jolson, Pollitt, Cashel],
Calkins and L. Cattanach. The
captain of the team will not be
elected until after the first game,.
December 19.
Basket-ball has not been recog. nized by the Hopkins Athletic
-Board until this year. It is now
rated as a minor sport:
Games for the Coining season
have been booked with the stiongest college teams of the East—
Princeton, Dartmouth, Navy and
the University of Pennsylvania
all being included in the list of
prospective opponents of the Black
and Blue quintet. With the excepWm Of one date, the schedule,
which extends for nearly three
months, is completely filled. Eight
of the fourteen contests will take
place in this city at the :Baltimore
Athletic Club gymnasium'. The
tentative schedule, as announced
by Ma mtger.Kennady, follows:

December 26—Union College, at home.

HOWARD AND LEXINGTON STS.

A Gateway—Electrical
NLY a forty-foot gateway bounded by
two brick pilasters and ornamental
lamps, but unlike any other gateway in the
entire world.

O

For back of it is the General Electric Company's main office building, accommodating
2300 employees. And just next door is its
laboratory with the best equipment for testing, standardizing and research at the command of capable engineers. Then down the
street—a mile long—are other buildings
where everything electrical,from the smallest lamp socket to the huge turbines for
electrically propelled battl3ships, is made

•

by the 20,000 electrical workers who daily
stream through.
What a story this gate would tell, if it could,
of the leaders of the electrical industry and
business, of ambassadors from other institutions and from foreign lands.
The story would be the history of electric
lighting, electric transportation, electric industrials and electricity in the home.
This gateway, as well as the research, engineering, manufacturing and commercial
resources back of it, is open to all who are
working for the betterment of the electrical
industry.

BALTIMORE, MD.,

DEC. 2, 1919

A Good Opportunity.

In most universities it is the custom for the graduating class to
leave a memorial behind. Several
classes have attempted to start
that tradition here, one instance
being the sun dial in the botanical gardens. The opportunity now
presents itself for the seniors t()
set the example for the othei•
classes at the University, and for
them to establish more firmly tha
tradition for coming classes to observe.
Each class is separately subscribing to the dormitory fund.
Each class should leave behind it
a memorial. It would seem most
expedient that the money which
would be put into a memorial be
included in the subscriptions to
the much-needed dormitory. Undoubtedly the chairman of the
Alumni Committee would be willing to have this class memorial
subscription set aside to furnish
a memorial room or establish some
special feature in the future home
of Hopkins men.
No class memorial could be more
useful or fitting. In this way the
new men could be made to feel
mere strongly the college devotion
and interest of their predecessors.
If the Senior Class wishes to exert
a beneficial influence in some way
over the lives of future undergradmites, here is its chances.

Saila Improvement in News-Letter.
To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTEH:

Sir—I just want to use a small
space in your letter cOluttin to express by delight at the recent very
marked improvement in THE
NEWS-LETTER. Your news is interesting and well written, the
editorials are above par and the
last few issues. have been made
even more attractive by the insertion of a few photographs. As
business manager of the Hullabaloo, I am in a position to appreciate what this latest innovation
means; namely, a competent business manager. Plates of this kind
are rather expensive, especially at
this time, and I consider it a real

QUACKS FROM A QUACK
rnimportant as they may seem,
the faculty claim that they have
a legal, if not a moral, right to a
little publicity in my all-scholastic
column, and much as I hate to do
it, I will bore you with some of
the things they consider amusing.
Dr. Gilpin wishes to announce
that with the very able assistance
of the famous chemist, Freshman
Lawrence Guin, he has been able
to develop and perfect a formula
for the removal of paint. It is to
sit in it before it is dry.
Dr. Hulburt, our widely known
mathematical wizard, takes this
opportunity to state that he was
not the originator ( as so many
thought) of the headline in a recent edition of the Evening Star,
which read,"Plan to do away with
parallel lines." According to the
illustrious doctor, this headline
was ill some way or other connected , with the plans or the
United Railways and not a lifesaver to Second Class Private
Veasey, who can't for the life of
I im see why parallel. lines should
meet at infinity—whei ever that is.
They say, although 1 won't
vouch for the truth of it, that the
following old joke was pulled off
on Dr. Whiteman : Upon being
asked how to make a maltese
one of time artists by the name of
Dodson answered, "Pull its tail."

kick goal. There was no further
score that half, and the game was
called by Dr. Abercrombie directly after the kick-off in the second

BALTIMORE

With a squad of fifty men practicing three times a week at the
Baltimore Athletic Club tinder the
direction of Coach Murphy, prospects for a successful season for
the first basket-ball team representing Hopkins are exceedingly
bright. The first practice session
was called by Manager I.3ascom
Kennady on Monday, November
17, and since then practice has
been held regularly on Mondays,
Wednesdays and Thursdays, from
9 to 11. P. M.
On the squad are several freshmen who were formerly prominent
members of local "prep" school
fives. Owens and Beigle, of
Friends School and City College;
respectively, have both made enviable records as forwards. The position of center is also being hotly
contested for by two very capable
fresh, Bauernschmidt, of City College, and Ward,of Baltimore Polytechnic Institute. Among the
graduate students eligible to play
are five men from the medical college—Cuano, Love, Sherrick, Weinert and Sheffey, all of whom have
been connected with teams .of
other colleges. The remainder of
the squad, which is composed of
undergraduates, includes athletes
of stich calibre as "Bill" and "Ed"
Wood, Jolson, Pollitt, Cashel],
Calkins and L. Cattanach. The
captain of the team will not be
elected until after the first game,.
December 19.
Basket-ball has not been recog. nized by the Hopkins Athletic
-Board until this year. It is now
rated as a minor sport:
Games for the Coining season
have been booked with the stiongest college teams of the East—
Princeton, Dartmouth, Navy and
the University of Pennsylvania
all being included in the list of
prospective opponents of the Black
and Blue quintet. With the excepWm Of one date, the schedule,
which extends for nearly three
months, is completely filled. Eight
of the fourteen contests will take
place in this city at the :Baltimore
Athletic Club gymnasium'. The
tentative schedule, as announced
by Ma mtger.Kennady, follows:

A Gateway—Electrical
NLY a forty-foot gateway bounded by
two brick pilasters and ornamental
lamps, but unlike any other gateway in the
entire world.

O

For back of it is the General Electric Company's main office building, accommodating
2300 employees. And just next door is its
laboratory with the best equipment for testing, standardizing and research at the command of capable engineers. Then down the
street—a mile long—are other buildings
where everything electrical,from the smallest lamp socket to the huge turbines for
electrically propelled battl3ships, is made

•

by the 20,000 electrical workers who daily
stream through.
What a story this gate would tell, if it could,
of the leaders of the electrical industry and
business, of ambassadors from other institutions and from foreign lands.
The story would be the history of electric
lighting, electric transportation, electric industrials and electricity in the home.
This gateway, as well as the research, engineering, manufacturing and commercial
resources back of it, is open to all who are
working for the betterment of the electrical
industry.

A Good Opportunity.

In most universities it is the custom for the graduating class to
leave a memorial behind. Several
classes have attempted to start
that tradition here, one instance
being the sun dial in the botanical gardens. The opportunity now
presents itself for the seniors t()
set the example for the othei•
classes at the University, and for
them to establish more firmly tha
tradition for coming classes to observe.
Each class is separately subscribing to the dormitory fund.
Each class should leave behind it
a memorial. It would seem most
expedient that the money which
would be put into a memorial be
included in the subscriptions to
the much-needed dormitory. Undoubtedly the chairman of the
Alumni Committee would be willing to have this class memorial
subscription set aside to furnish
a memorial room or establish some
special feature in the future home
of Hopkins men.
No class memorial could be more
useful or fitting. In this way the
new men could be made to feel
mere strongly the college devotion
and interest of their predecessors.
If the Senior Class wishes to exert
a beneficial influence in some way
over the lives of future undergradmites, here is its chances.

To the Editor of THE NEws-LETTEH:

Sir—I just want to use a small
space in your letter cOluttin to express by delight at the recent very
marked improvement in THE
NEWS-LETTER. Your news is interesting and well written, the
editorials are above par and the
last few issues. have been made
even more attractive by the insertion of a few photographs. As
business manager of the Hullabaloo, I am in a position to appreciate what this latest innovation
means; namely, a competent business manager. Plates of this kind
are rather expensive, especially at
this time, and I consider it a real

QUACKS FROM A QUACK
rnimportant as they may seem,
the faculty claim that they have
a legal, if not a moral, right to a
little publicity in my all-scholastic
column, and much as I hate to do
it, I will bore you with some of
the things they consider amusing.
Dr. Gilpin wishes to announce
that with the very able assistance
of the famous chemist, Freshman
Lawrence Guin, he has been able
to develop and perfect a formula
for the removal of paint. It is to
sit in it before it is dry.
Dr. Hulburt, our widely known
mathematical wizard, takes this
opportunity to state that he was
not the originator ( as so many
thought) of the headline in a recent edition of the Evening Star,
which read,"Plan to do away with
parallel lines." According to the
illustrious doctor, this headline
was ill some way or other connected , with the plans or the
United Railways and not a lifesaver to Second Class Private
Veasey, who can't for the life of
I im see why parallel. lines should
meet at infinity—whei ever that is.
They say, although 1 won't
vouch for the truth of it, that the
following old joke was pulled off
on Dr. Whiteman : Upon being
asked how to make a maltese
one of time artists by the name of
Dodson answered, "Pull its tail."
The irate lurofessor stormed, "Sir,
I see no connection between it
111:11tese cross and a pullet's tail:''
And as one man the assembly of
draftsmen rose and cried : -Figure
it out for yourself, Doctor, figure
it out for yourself."

have derived untold benefit front
it. When the barrel was first taken
to my room two days ago I could
hardly lift it, now I can carry it
with the greatest ease."
The other day Professor Christie
attested with a great deal of emphasis and vigor that it is the hill
that produces the echo. And here
we have lived all these years thinking it was the holler.

Juniors Ahead at End of First Half.

on Monday.

An
interesting game
was
brought to an end last Wednesday
when Dr. Abercrombie stopped the
contest between the junior athletes
and the Red Eagles. Although the
game was scheduled for 4 o'clock,
aml this time found the juniors all
present, it was not until 4.45 that
the Red Eagles made their appearance. On account of this delay it
became so (lark at the beginning
of the second half that Dr. Abercrombie was forced to call the
game.
The field was very slippery and
muddy, and there were many fumbles. Both sides played with a
great deal of spirit. The juniors,
as was to be expected, -displayed
better teamwork, while the Eagles
seemed to have the best individual
players The Eagles were often
penalized for offside. There was
110 score until near the end of the
second half when Evans got the
ball on a fumble on the Eagles'
8-yard line. In three downs the
juniors were able to gain but one
yard. Ott the fourth down, however, Baughman went through the
Eagles line for TO yards and
it touchdown. The juniors failed to
kick goal. There was no further
score that half, and the game was
called by Dr. Abercrombie directly after the kick-off in the second
